title: Ticket #974: NMI Glue is a Pit of Despair
description:
While testing my glue changes for #715, I've run into an ever deepening pool of suck.

The high level view of it is that apparently, years ago when the glue (specifically nmi_tools/ and nmi_glue/) was written, an assumption was made that there would be only a single authoritative source for this glue, for all branches, and that it would live at the end of the trunk. Our nightly builds assume it, the workspace build assumes it, even building a certain tag or branch assumes it. Due to the happy coincidence that our glue scripts, and how they interact with our sources and tests, are identical across all of our branches at this time, our builds and tests work on a day to day basis.

This assumption has made it nearly impossible for one to test any changes in a branch to the glue without propagating it all the way to the master and thereby contaminating the nightly builds and whatnot with untested code.

After moderate inspection of condor_nmi_submit, how our nightlies work, and so forth, I've come to the conclusion that there were initial design problems which were never solved, punted on, and are now causing the pain.

Some design problems are:

  • All of our branches have nmi_glue and nmi_tools, yet only the origin/master instance is actually used during BUILD and TEST runs. This is especially apparent in the nightlies, no matter which tag you are building. The existence of those directories in each branch produced an implication that glue scripts are local to a branch and will only affect the building of that branch. From a developer point of view, the glue associated with the branch *should be* the glue used to make and test that branch.
    Fixed. See #1195

  • In workspace builds, it is somewhat unclear to me which glue actually gets used. It appears to me that the glue used in the BUILD stage is the one from the workspace, but the glue used in the TEST stage is the one from origin/master. From a developer's point of view, both instances of the glue should be from the workspace itself.

  • One cannot correctly test glue changes without contaminating all builds and tests for all branches including nightlies.

  • In the nightlies, condor_nmi_submit is responsible for finding the nightly tags file and submitting the builds and tests. Since we don't have a condor_nmi_submit, we get one from origin/master and call that one. This means we use origin/master's glue for all branches built. From a developer's point of view, the nightly.pl script should parse the tags, checkout the correct version of nmi_tools and nmi_glue, and then invoke that with the right branch tags so the build and tests gets the right glue.
    Fixed. See #1195 / #1397.

  • Even though there is one branch for the glue, the submit_info file is actually checked out from the individual branches in question in the nightlies and read by the condor_nmi_submit. This is crazy, as it means the format and meaning of that file must be identical across all branches because it is only read by one version of the glue!
    Made obselete by #1195 / #1397. The SubmitInfo.pm file now matches the condor_nmi_submit that uses it.

  • While doing work for #366, I came across another problem. I was adding new targets to condor_tests/Imakefile and found that the NMI glue builds the tests in the test suite in a radically different manner than how a developer does it. Basically, the test glue builds a few named targets, then each test actually needing to be run is build independently. Since some of those tests rely on a new dependency which has to exist in the toplevel condor_tests/ directory, I'd have to add a new make invocation in the glue to ensure it exists. Make can't do it itself, because there are completely separate Makefiles in condor_tests/ condor_tests/gcc condor_tests/g77 condor_tests/gpp condor_tests/f90 that don't really know about each other.

  • I found that changing the glue in a certain manner, suppose altering the syntax or presence of the submit_info file, causes the new glue to be unable to build previous incarnation or tags of Condor which predate the glue change. This is due to the head of the master trying to find what it think to be the correct files or state in older tags or branches. Basically, the NMI Glue not only expects to see an identical version of itself across all branches, but also across all time on those branches.

  • The nightly.pl script, which fires off the nightly builds is only valid at origin/master. Worse than that, the nightly.pl script updates itself as it is running from cron, meaning if you make a change to it, the nightlies on the day you made the change won't see it, but the next nightlies will, unless you manually update the copy in ~cndrauto/condor on nmi-s006.
    See #1195 / #1397 for now it works sanely.
